markdown:
[Undead](/Traits.aspx?ID=722) are plentiful throughout the Gravelands, but even so, necromancers must sometimes get creative to organize the varied undead they have on hand into a cohesive military unit. While the typical raised cavalry is a mix of [skeletons](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=472), [zombies](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=487), and [ghouls](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=419), many units also incorporate [mummies](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=445), [ghosts](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=418), and more powerful undead. The Knights of Lastwall have reported battalions of undead rising from the fields where they were buried, presumably in preparation for a future assault. One of the most infamous of these staging grounds was Fallowdeep, the network of subterranean tunnels beneath the former dwarven fortress of Hammer Rock. When the Whispering Tyrant attacked the nations of the Inner Sea, Fallowdeep's supply of undead was vastly depleted, but caches of corpses no doubt remain there for a resourceful necromancer to exploit. **[Recall Knowledge - Undead](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Religion](/Skills.aspx?ID=46)): DC 41 **[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 39 **[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 36 [Raised Cavalry](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3827) **Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 118 **Perception** +32; darkvision **Languages** [Common](/Languages.aspx?ID=1), [Necril](/Languages.aspx?ID=20) **Skills** [Athletics](/Skills.aspx?ID=36) +37 **Str** +10 **Dex** +5 **Con** +6 **Int** +5 **Wis** +6 **Cha** +6 **Mounted** When not mounted, the raised cavalry is slowed 1.
 --- **AC** 42 **Fort** +29 **Ref** +28 **Will** +31 **HP** 360 (4 segments, [void healing](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=83)) **Immunities** [bleed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=86), [death effects](/Traits.aspx?ID=571), [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=578), [paralyzed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=85), [poison](/Traits.aspx?ID=669), [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=95) **Resistances** physical 20 **Weaknesses** [area damage](/Rules.aspx?ID=2384) 20, [splash damage](/Traits.aspx?ID=699) 20, [vitality](/Traits.aspx?ID=509) 20 **Shuffle Forces** The raised cavalry consists of [skeletons](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=472), [zombies](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=487), and other [undead](/Traits.aspx?ID=722) hastily bound to a shared cause. The cavalry has resistance 20 to physical damage, as it shuffles its weakest members to the front lines. When the cavalry is reduced to 12 squares or fewer, its resistance to physical drops to 10. Once the cavalry reaches the 2-segment threshold, it loses its resistance to physical damage.
[Troop Defenses](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=86) --- **Speed** 40 feet; [troop movement](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=85) **Claws and Jaws** **Frequency** once per round; **Effect** Members of the cavalry leap from their mounts and attack each enemy within 10 feet (DC 41 [basic](/Rules.aspx?ID=2297) Reflex save). The damage depends on the number of actions.
2d12+14 piercing and slashing plus 1d12 [void](/Traits.aspx?ID=510)
3d12+14 piercing and slashing plus 1d12 void
4d12+14 piercing and slashing plus 1d12 void **Hail of Arrows** Members of the raised cavalry draw or reload their shortbows, then launch a ranged attack in the form of a volley. This volley is a 10-foot [burst](/Rules.aspx?ID=2385) within 60 feet that deals 7d8 piercing damage (DC 41 [basic](/Rules.aspx?ID=2297) Reflex save). When the cavalry is reduced to 2 segments, this area decreases to a 5-foot burst. **Trampling Charge** The raised cavalry [Strides](/Actions.aspx?ID=2305) twice with a +10-foot circumstance bonus to its Speed. During this movement, the cavalry can move through the spaces of Medium or smaller creatures. It deals 3d12+14 bludgeoning damage to each creature whose space it moves through (DC 41 [basic](/Rules.aspx?ID=2297) Reflex save). A creature that fails its save is also knocked [prone](/Conditions.aspx?ID=88). The cavalry can affect the same creature only once in a single use of Trampling Charge. **[Troop Movement](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=85)**
A Cavalry Without Mounts Outfitting a raised cavalry with sufficient mounts typically involves the slaughter of horses on a massive scale. The destruction of a horse ranch, sudden disappearance of a wild herd, or an increase in travelers robbed of their mounts might signal a necromantic plot afoot. Without horses or other undead mounts to ride, a raised cavalry is [slowed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=92) 1.
name: Raised Cavalry

<title level="1" pfs="">[Splinter Officer](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3828)</title>

<row gap="medium">

<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

An army of [mindless](/Traits.aspx?ID=652) [undead](/Traits.aspx?ID=722) possesses a fatal flaw: it requires near-constant babysitting from its maker. Yet, any undead with enough sentience to command such an army runs the risk of turning on its creator. Skilled necromancers have endeavored to strike a balance between these two extremes with the creation of splinter officers. Capable of leading small battalions of undead, splinter officers are at the same time uniquely bound to their creator—and easily disposed of should they ever decide to go rogue. 

The first splinter officer was created when a [lich](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=438) separated his soul cage into multiple parts and implanted each shard into a unique undead champion, over which the lich enjoyed complete control. Ultimately, the lich decided the risk to his soul cage wasn't worth the benefits, but the technique of soul-splitting proved too useful to abandon. Today, splinter officers are created by plucking an intelligent creature's soul from [Pharasma's](/Deities.aspx?ID=290) clutches at the moment of the creature's death. The fresh soul is then shattered, with the splinter officer receiving the largest portion and the remaining splinters being implanted into the mindless undead soldiers the officer controls.

<column gap="tiny">
**[Recall Knowledge - Undead](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**
([Religion](/Skills.aspx?ID=46)): DC 41

**[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 39

**[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 36
</column>

</column>

<column gap="medium">

</column>

</row>

<title level="2" right="Creature 19">[Splinter Officer](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3828)</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Uncommon" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=721" />
<trait label="Medium" />
<trait label="Undead" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=722" />
<trait label="Unholy" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=521" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

**Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 119

**Perception** +35; darkvision 120 feet, splintersense

**Languages**
[Common](/Languages.aspx?ID=1), [Necril](/Languages.aspx?ID=20)

**Skills**
[Acrobatics](/Skills.aspx?ID=34) +30, [Deception](/Skills.aspx?ID=38) +37, [Diplomacy](/Skills.aspx?ID=39) +37, [Warfare Lore](/Skills.aspx?ID=41) +39

<row gap="medium">
**Str** +4

**Dex** +6

**Con** +5

**Int** +5

**Wis** +4

**Cha** +10
</row>

**Splintersense** ([divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=579), [mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=647)) The splinter officer knows the direction and distance of all [undead](/Traits.aspx?ID=722) that share splinters of the same splinter officer's soul. These undead are always considered to be allies of the splinter officer.

**Items**
_[+2 greater resilient](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2786) [chain shirt](/Armor.aspx?ID=43)_, _[+2 greater striking](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2829) [longbow](/Weapons.aspx?ID=436)_, _[+2 greater striking](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2829) [keen](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2843) [rapier](/Weapons.aspx?ID=391)_

</column>

---

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="medium">
**AC** 42 

**Fort** +32 

**Ref** +35 

**Will** +36 

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**HP** 375
([void healing](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=83))

</row>

**Immunities**
[bleed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=86), [death effects](/Traits.aspx?ID=571), [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=578), [doomed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=67), [drained](/Conditions.aspx?ID=68), [fatigued](/Conditions.aspx?ID=73), [healing](/Traits.aspx?ID=623), [nonlethal](/Traits.aspx?ID=661), [paralyzed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=85), [poison](/Traits.aspx?ID=669), [sickened](/Conditions.aspx?ID=91), [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=95)

**Resistances**
[cold](/Traits.aspx?ID=555) 20, [electricity](/Traits.aspx?ID=586) 20, [fire](/Traits.aspx?ID=604) 20, piercing 20, slashing 20

**Weaknesses**
[vitality](/Traits.aspx?ID=509) 15

**Behind the Lines** <actions string="Reaction" />  **Trigger** The splinter officer is targeted by an attack; **Requirements** At least one of the officer's undead allies is adjacent to the officer; **Effect** The ally interposes itself, granting the officer a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against the triggering attack.

</column>

---

<column gap="tiny">

**Speed** 30 feet

**Melee**
<actions string="Single Action" />
_rapier_ +34 ([deadly d8](/Traits.aspx?ID=174), [Disarm](/Traits.aspx?ID=175), [Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103)),
**Damage** 4d6+15 piercing

**Ranged**
<actions string="Single Action" />
_longbow_ +34 ([deadly d10](/Traits.aspx?ID=174), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103), [Propulsive](/Traits.aspx?ID=191), [range increment 100 feet](/Traits.aspx?ID=248), [volley 30 feet](/Traits.aspx?ID=201)),
**Damage** 4d8+15 piercing

**Raise Defenses** <actions string="Two Actions" /> ([Concentrate](/Traits.aspx?ID=32), [Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48)) The splinter officer mentally commands its undead allies to strengthen their defenses. For 1 round, each undead that shares the officer's splintered soul gains a +1 circumstance bonus to AC.

**Rally the Rabble** <actions string="Three Actions" /> ([Concentrate](/Traits.aspx?ID=32), [Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48)) The splinter officer mentally energizes the undead under its command. Each undead that shares the officer's splintered soul is [quickened](/Conditions.aspx?ID=89) for 1 round. Quickened allies can use the extra action only to [Stride](/Actions.aspx?ID=2305) or [Strike](/Actions.aspx?ID=2306). The officer can't Rally the Rabble again for 1d4 rounds.

**Synchronized Step** <actions string="Two Actions" /> ([Concentrate](/Traits.aspx?ID=32), [Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48)) The splinter officer mentally commands the undead that share its splintered soul to reposition. The officer [Steps](/Actions.aspx?ID=2304), and each undead that shares the officer's splintered soul can use a reaction to Step.

</column>

<aside>
<title level="2" noclass="true" icon="/images/Icons/Sidebar_2_AdditionalLore.png">The Splintered Soul</title>

How finely a soul can be divided remains uncertain, but thus far none have been split into more than 50 pieces, including the shard used to raise the splinter officer. Depending on the desires of its creator, the splinter officer might be given the unused pieces of its soul to raise additional [undead](/Traits.aspx?ID=722) while in the field. However, a necromancer paranoid enough to rely on a splinter officer to command their undead legion rarely sacrifices such power willingly.
</aside>
name: Splinter Officer

markdown:
Stelemoras are nature-loving [fey](/Traits.aspx?ID=599) dedicated to beautifying the natural world by ensnaring unsuspecting creatures and transforming their bodies into elaborate topiaries from the inside out. Aside from their bulbous, spiked seed pods, stelemoras are composed entirely of vines, which they can grow, retract, and shed at will. Stelemoras regrow damaged vines at an alarming rate, allowing them to recover from nearly any injury over time. Young stelemoras travel the world looking for a piece of wilderness to call their own. Once they select a proper spot, they use their vines to snare passing creatures, holding their target still as they forcibly implant their seeds inside the victim. The implanted seeds then take root, using the creature itself as fertilizer and slowly transforming its body into a mass of vines and leaves. Once they complete their work, the stelemora sheds their vines and regrows in a new location to begin their next masterpiece. While stelemoras prefer to fill their gardens with once-living creatures, they entomb inanimate objects in vines if they can't capture their preferred subjects. Stelemoras have also been known to transform statues, treasure chests, and even entire buildings into topiaries in order to lure in their favored prey. **[Recall Knowledge - Fey](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Nature](/Skills.aspx?ID=43)): DC 25 **[Recall Knowledge - Plant](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Nature](/Skills.aspx?ID=43)): DC 25 **[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 23 **[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 20 [Stelemora](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3829) **Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 120 **Perception** +17; low-light vision **Languages** [Common](/Languages.aspx?ID=1), [Fey](/Languages.aspx?ID=119) **Skills** [Athletics](/Skills.aspx?ID=36) +17, [Nature](/Skills.aspx?ID=43) +17, [Stealth](/Skills.aspx?ID=48) +15, [Survival](/Skills.aspx?ID=49) +16 **Str** +4 **Dex** +2 **Con** +3 **Int** +1 **Wis** +6 **Cha** +3 --- **AC** 24 **Fort** +15 **Ref** +14 **Will** +17 **HP** 188 , regeneration 20 (deactivated by fire) **Weaknesses** [cold iron](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2916) 10, [fire](/Traits.aspx?ID=604) 10 --- **Speed** 25 feet **Melee** vine +17 ([reach 10 feet](/Traits.aspx?ID=684)), **Damage** 2d8+8 bludgeoning plus [Grab](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=45) **Melee** seed pod +17, **Damage** 2d10+8 piercing **[Constrict](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=57)** 1d8+8 bludgeoning, DC 25 **Flurry of Vines** The stelemora makes two vine Strikes at a –2 penalty, each against a different target. These attacks count toward the stelemora's multiple attack penalty, but the multiple attack penalty doesn't increase until after they make all their attacks. **Slithering Vine** The stelemora increases the [reach](/Traits.aspx?ID=684) of their vine Strike by 10 feet until the end of their turn. **Sow and Sprout** The stelemora implants a seed inside a creature they're grappling. The target must attempt a DC 25 Fortitude save.
**Success** The stelemora fails to implant a seed, and the target is unaffected.
**Failure** The target is [sickened](/Conditions.aspx?ID=91) 1. While sickened, the target also takes 4d6 [persistent piercing damage](/Conditions.aspx?ID=86) as flowering vines sprout through its flesh. The target can't end the persistent damage until it recovers from the sickened condition.
**Critical Failure** As failure, except the target is sickened 2. **Tangle of Vines** ([Concentrate](/Traits.aspx?ID=32)) Until the next time they act, the stelemora appears to be a normal tangle of flowering vines. They have an automatic result of 35 (38 in forests) on [Deception](/Skills.aspx?ID=38) checks and DCs to pass as a non-creature plant.
Royal Gardeners Stelemoras sometimes serve [hamadryads](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3114) and other noble fey as gardeners, decorating their courtyards with fantastic sculptures formed from flowering vines. Kindly rulers typically demand that stelemoras in their employ limit their creations to inanimate subjects, but crueler fey place no such restrictions on their gardeners' creativity.
name: Stelemora

While many [celestials](/Languages.aspx?ID=16) are drawn to what is, tallusians care about what was. Compelled to protect the remnants of fallen civilizations, tallusians often work alongside [dryads](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3112) and other creatures of nature, helping restore the land around their ruins while fighting off evil influences seeking to claim the abandoned structures for themselves. Though few know more about the ancient civilizations they protect than the tallusians themselves, they rarely make distinctions between holy sites and those used for nefarious purposes. To a tallusian, any building, regardless of its history, can be repurposed into something new. Physically, tallusians resemble oversized red pandas, except they have six legs, piercing blue eyes, and quills of sharpened stone growing along their backs and from their bushy tails. At rest, tallusians appear virtually indistinguishable from the buildings they protect, masquerading as heaps of rubble until they move. They also possess the ability to adopt a humanoid form, often that of an energetic child. Tallusians disguised as children have been known to lead adventurers to civilizations that have otherwise fallen off the map, in hopes the heroes will help protect the ruins until they can be restored. **[Recall Knowledge - Celestial](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Religion](/Skills.aspx?ID=46)): DC 22 **[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 20 **[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 17 [Tallusian](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3830) **Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 121 **Perception** +12; darkvision **Languages** [Empyrean](/Languages.aspx?ID=115), [Fey](/Languages.aspx?ID=119); _truespeech_ **Skills** [Acrobatics](/Skills.aspx?ID=34) +11, [Architecture Lore](/Skills.aspx?ID=41) +14, [Athletics](/Skills.aspx?ID=36) +11, [Crafting](/Skills.aspx?ID=37) +13, [Nature](/Skills.aspx?ID=43) +13, [Stealth](/Skills.aspx?ID=48) +11, [Survival](/Skills.aspx?ID=49) +13 **Str** +2 **Dex** +2 **Con** +4 **Int** +1 **Wis** +3 **Cha** +2 --- **AC** 21 **Fort** +14 **Ref** +12 **Will** +12 **HP** 76 **Weaknesses** [cold iron](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2916) 5, unholy 5 --- **Speed** 25 feet, climb 20 feet **Melee** jaws +14, **Damage** 2d8+8 piercing **Melee** claw +14 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170)), **Damage** 2d6+6 slashing **Melee** tail +14, **Damage** 2d6+6 bludgeoning plus Knockdown **Ranged** quill +14 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [range increment 20 feet](/Traits.aspx?ID=248)), **Damage** 2d6+6 piercing **Divine Innate Spells** DC 22 - **1st** [Pummeling Rubble](/Spells.aspx?ID=708) - **2nd** [Humanoid Form](/Spells.aspx?ID=153) (at will) - **4th** [Shape Stone](/Spells.aspx?ID=276) - **Constant (5th)** [Truespeech](/Spells.aspx?ID=1728) **Crumbling Ground** ([Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48), [Earth](/Traits.aspx?ID=55)) The tallusian slaps their tail against the earth, creating a vibration at the precise frequency needed to shake the ground in a 10-foot burst within 30 feet. The area becomes [difficult terrain](/Rules.aspx?ID=2366) for 24 hours. Any creature in the area must attempt a DC 22 Reflex save.
**Critical Success** The creature is unaffected.
**Success** The creature is [off-guard](/Conditions.aspx?ID=58) until the start of its next turn.
**Failure** The creature falls [prone](/Conditions.aspx?ID=88).
**Critical Failure** As failure, plus the creature takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage. **Rubble** ([Concentrate](/Traits.aspx?ID=32)) Until the next time it acts, the tallusian appears to be a normal pile of broken rubble. It has an automatic result of 31 (34 in ruins) on [Deception](/Skills.aspx?ID=38) checks and DCs to pass as a pile of rubble. **Tail Spin** The tallusian spins in place, sweeping their tail to knock down their foes. Each adjacent foe takes 2d6+6 bludgeoning damage (DC 22 [basic](/Rules.aspx?ID=2297) Reflex save). Also on a failed save, the target is knocked [prone](/Conditions.aspx?ID=88). Afterward, the tallusian becomes [clumsy](/Conditions.aspx?ID=61) 1 for 1 round.
Excessive Exuberance With their ability to shapeshift and seemingly limitless energy, tallusians are often mistaken as [fey](/Traits.aspx?ID=599) by the adventurers who encounter them. Indeed, many tallusians feel more comfortable among creatures of the [First World](/Planes.aspx?ID=35) than those of the celestial realms. [Angels](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=359) and even other [azatas](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=368) sometimes feel the intensity with which tallusians protect their ruins to be excessive. At heart, however, tallusians are as kindhearted as they are exuberant, flying into a frenzy of tooth, claw, and quill only when they feel their territory is at risk.
name: Tallusian

<title level="1" pfs="">[Commander Arsiella Dei](/NPCs.aspx?ID=3831)</title>

<row gap="medium">

<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

Arsiella Dei was born to be a Chernasardo Ranger. The youngest daughter of trapper-turned-military-leader Irgal Nirmath, who was assassinated in 4655 ar after the disorganized groups of rangers he brought together under a common banner gained their independence from Molthune, Arsiella grew up hearing stories of her father's exploits in a nation named in his honor. 

Had she been raised in a different time or place, Arsiella might have been an artist, but instead she began her training under the members of her father's former army, Irgal's Axe, from the time she could walk. Except for the occasional portrait sketched in the margins of her notebook, throughout her childhood Arsiella remained singularly focused on continuing her father's work of keeping Nirmathas a free nation. From her tutors, she learned not only how to wield an axe and bow, but also the arts of stealth, subterfuge, and sabotage. Arsiella was by all accounts considered an excellent student, no less cunning, clever, or insightful than Irgal Nirmath himself. 

While her father's compatriots taught Arsiella from an early age, they also spoiled her, often going easier on her than they would another sparring partner. As a result, by the time she was an adolescent, Arsiella believed she was nearly invincible. She took outsized risks on her patrols, sometimes endangering not only her own life, but those of her companions. In this way, Arsiella differed from her father, who always tempered his willingness to risk his own life with a concern for the safety of those under his command. Arsiella knew that if she wanted to become a leader of her people, she would need wisdom as well as skill, but it wasn't until she nearly died at the hands of a Molthuni advance line that she realized the importance of leaving her familiar surroundings of the Southern Fangwood to gain experience abroad. 

Arsiella relocated to Lastwall, where she sought tutelage under the Knights of Ozem, a military order dedicated to the goddess Iomedae. In Vigil, the capital of Lastwall at that time, she became a devout follower of the Inheritor, admiring both the goddess's strength and her sense of justice. During this period, Arsiella took the last name Dei, an appellation meant not only to honor her new goddess but to minimize the special treatment she might receive as the daughter of a famous war hero such as Irgal Nirmath. 

In Lastwall, Arsiella also built upon her long-standing belief in the importance of mastering different combat styles. Her teachers among the Knights of Ozem taught her how to fight undead, of course, but they also helped her develop the discipline and military regimen she so sorely lacked throughout her youth. In return, Arsiella became a teacher in her own right, instructing younger, inexperienced knights (many of whom would themselves go on to become Crimson Reclaimers) in the value of stealth, survival, and guerrilla warfare. To this day, Arsiella fights using techniques borrowed from the Chernasardo Rangers and the Knights of Ozem, a combination that makes her unique among the members of both those organizations. 

Arsiella wasn't in Vigil when it was destroyed in 4719 ar, but she was among the first of the forces to return to the city to take a reckoning of the damage that had occurred. Only when it became clear that Tar-Baphon had escaped his prison and that his undead forces were in the process of overwhelming Lastwall did she retreat, along with the Knights of Ozem, to the port city of Vellumis. As Lastwall died and the Gravelands rose to take its place, Arsiella was vital to the reestablishment of the Knights of Ozem, though she refused to become a Knight of Lastwall herself. In this way, Arsiella's years of training came to a fruition—though it pained her to leave her comrades-in-arms behind, she believed her talents would be put to better use mustering foreign forces for the greater battle against the Whispering Tyrant that was surely to come. 

By the time she returned to the Southern Fangwood, Arsiella had become both a battle-hardened warrior and a formidable strategist, and she quickly rose through the ranks to become one of the few Chernasardo wardens. While the rangers continued to be a loose confederation of freedom fighters, Arsiella possessed an uncanny ability to coordinate operations using a combination of charm, intimidation, and meticulous organization. This ability, along with her time serving with the Knights of Ozem and her devotion to Iomedae, earned Arsiella her role as the commander of Fort Ozem. When the time came to find a resting place for the Chalice of Ozem, Fort Ozem was the obvious choice, and Arsiella gladly assumed the role of the artifact's chief protector. Arsiella isn't one to be overly impressed by titles, but she sees her appointment as a way to continue her father's legacy, and she has used a bit of her pull to afford him a place of honor within the catacombs beneath the fort. She considers her regular visits to Irgal's tomb as both an honor to her father and a source of strength that helps her fulfill her current duties.

**Campaign Role**

Arsiella Dei oversees Fort Ozem as the PCs infiltrate the outpost in search of the Chalice of Ozem. Of all the fort's defenders, only Arsiella is aware of the Chalice's presence in the catacombs. Arsiella takes the secrecy of the artifact's presence in the fort with the utmost seriousness. She's long believed that her father's assassination was made possible only because someone inadvertently revealed his location, and she has vowed not to let her knowledge of the fort's true purpose fall into evil hands.

In her time as fort commander, Arsiella has increased the use of traps in the forward “sword” section of Fort Ozem. She's also made deals with local [fey](/Traits.aspx?ID=599) and other creatures to add an additional level of security throughout the fort, trusting these creatures to repel intruders should the fort's humanoid defenders fail or prove untrustworthy. She views herself as the Chalice of Ozem's last line of defense, however. If presented with unbeatable odds, Arsiella abandons the fort with the Chalice. Before then, anyone who enters Fort Ozem without her permission is likely to face a hail of arrows from her bow or the sharp side of her axe.

markdown:
The tale of Seldeg Bhedlis is one of bitterness and failure. Once a proud Knight of Ozem, Seldeg fought alongside [Arazni](/Deities.aspx?ID=326), then still the herald of [Aroden](/Deities.aspx?ID=512), during the Shining Crusade. He rose quickly through the ranks, and in 3889 ar, he was one of six knights handpicked to infiltrate the city of Mechitar to take down the nation of Geb from within. This appointment proved to be Seldeg's undoing. Until this point, Seldeg's life had been one of strict military regimen. Once freed from the shackles of morality imposed upon him by his upbringing, Seldeg found the pleasures of Geb too tempting to resist. He eventually fell into the arms of a vampire lover, who was herself a secret thrall to one of that nation's Blood Lords. Over the following weeks, Seldeg revealed to his new lover everything he knew about the Knights of Ozem, dealing irreparable damage to his former order. Recognizing that his actions would be viewed harshly by both Aroden and [Pharasma](/Deities.aspx?ID=290), Seldeg assented to becoming a [graveknight](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=423) rather than face the judgment of the gods. Seldeg's first task as a graveknight was to steal Arazni's body from Vigil, where it had been laid to rest after her defeat at the hands of the Whispering Tyrant. In this, at least, Seldeg succeeded. Upon the graveknight's return, Geb transformed Arazni into a lich and assigned Seldeg and his fellow fallen knights, now known as the Council Libertine, to serve as both her personal bodyguards and captors. Seldeg provided centuries of faithful service to the Ghost King, but eventually the graveknight failed again. In 4719 ar, spurred by a premonition of Tar-Baphon's return, Arazni escaped the Council Libertine, fled the nation of Geb, and returned to Lastwall. Weeks later, she was killed fighting the Whispering Tyrant alongside a group of mortal heroes and, as a consequence, was granted godhood. As punishment for allowing Arazni to escape, Geb appointed Seldeg with the unenviable task of covering up this failure. Despite the graveknight's best efforts, however, hiding Arazni's ascension proved impossible. When Seldeg learned that Geb planned to destroy his graveknight armor, the embittered graveknight fled to the Gravelands and pledged his service to a new master, Tar-Baphon. Still haunted by his failures, Seldeg has since become fixated on Arazni, whose history he believes mirrors his own. Like Arazni, Seldeg became undead largely against his will, then was forced to commit atrocities he would've otherwise abhorred had fate not set him down a grim path. The fallen knight now intends to repair Arazni's fate, along with his own, once and for all. To do so, he's devised a ritual that will swap Arazni's story with that of another goddess, [Iomedae](/Deities.aspx?ID=285). If successful, Seldeg believes he'll rewrite history such that Iomedae, and not Arazni, will have died at the hands of Tar-Baphon. **Campaign Role** Seldeg Bhedlis previously appeared in the Blood Lords Adventure Path, where the Ghost King Geb proposed killing the graveknight and destroying his cursed armor. Despite these machinations, Seldeg managed to survive, though his iconic armor was damaged during his escape. Geb's betrayal, along with Seldeg's growing discontent with his role as the Ghost King's spymaster, inspired the graveknight to defect from Geb and travel to the Gravelands to pledge his service to the Whispering Tyrant. While the characters might not realize it, Seldeg Bhedlis drives the story of all three adventures presented in Claws of the Tyrant. In each adventure, Seldeg's actions arise from his desperate (and arguably delusional) belief that by undoing Arazni's fate, he'll somehow change his own. Seldeg's bitterness, however, blinds him to the fact that his attempts to rewrite history lead him even further away from the redemption he so desperately seeks. In “Gravelands Survivors,” Seldeg sends one of his agents to the ruined village of Yua's Hope to retrieve one of the Bloodstones of Arazni, an artifact Seldeg believes is vital to powering his ritual. The heroes are among a group of refugees who must deliver the Bloodstone into safe hands. In “Ashes for Ozem,” Seldeg tasks the characters with stealing another relic, the [Chalice of Ozem](/Equipment.aspx?ID=3787), from Fort Ozem, a former Knights of Ozem stronghold now under the stewardship of the Chernasardo Rangers. Though the Chalice isn't required to enact his ritual, Seldeg believes an artifact so tied to the histories of Arazni and Iomedae will lend power to his magic. The book's final adventure, “Of Blood and Faith,” sees Seldeg undertaking the ritual to swap the fates of Arazni and Iomedae. In this adventure, the heroes race Seldeg's minions to recover the two still-missing Bloodstones. At the adventure's climax, the characters finally have the chance to confront Seldeg face-to-face and put an end to the graveknight's machinations once and for all. **[Recall Knowledge - Undead](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Religion](/Skills.aspx?ID=46)): DC 50 **[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 48 **[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 45 [Seldeg Bhedlis (Claws of the Tyrant)](/NPCs.aspx?ID=3832) **Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 125 **Perception** +32; darkvision **Languages** [Chthonian](/Languages.aspx?ID=114), [Common](/Languages.aspx?ID=1), [Diabolic](/Languages.aspx?ID=117), [Kelish](/Languages.aspx?ID=38), [Necril](/Languages.aspx?ID=20), [Osiriani](/Languages.aspx?ID=40) **Skills** [Arazni Lore](/Skills.aspx?ID=41) +38, [Athletics](/Skills.aspx?ID=36) +38, [Diplomacy](/Skills.aspx?ID=39) +34, [Intimidation](/Skills.aspx?ID=40) +34, [Religion](/Skills.aspx?ID=46) +32, [Society](/Skills.aspx?ID=47) +34, [Warfare Lore](/Skills.aspx?ID=41) +34 **Str** +10 **Dex** +6 **Con** +10 **Int** +7 **Wis** +4 **Cha** +7 **Items** _[+2 resilient](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2786) [standard-grade adamantine](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2915) [full plate](/Armor.aspx?ID=50)_, [Javelin](/Weapons.aspx?ID=71) (4), [Longsword](/Weapons.aspx?ID=31), _[supreme](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2811) [sturdy shield](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2828)_ (Hardness 20, HP 160, BT 80) --- **AC** 46 (48 with shield raised) **Fort** +36 **Ref** +32 **Will** +33 **HP** 465 (rejuvenation, [void healing](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=83)) **Immunities** [bleed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=86), [death effects](/Traits.aspx?ID=571), [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=578), [fire](/Traits.aspx?ID=604), [paralyzed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=85), [poison](/Traits.aspx?ID=669), [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=95) **Sacrilegious Aura** ([aura](/Traits.aspx?ID=542), [divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=579), [void](/Traits.aspx?ID=510)) 30 feet. Counteract modifier +31
**Iron Command** **Trigger** An enemy within 15 feet damages Seldeg; **Effect** Seldeg puts an impertinent foe who dared harm him in their proper place. He commands the enemy to kneel in obedience. If they refuse, they must pay the price in pain and anguish. The triggering creature must choose one of the following options: the enemy kneels, dropping [prone](/Conditions.aspx?ID=88) as a free action, or the enemy refuses and takes 6d6 mental damage. In addition, Seldeg's Strikes against the triggering creature deal an additional 3 damage until the end of his next turn. Seldeg chooses whether the additional damage is [spirit](/Traits.aspx?ID=737) or [void](/Traits.aspx?ID=510) each time he uses this reaction.
[**Reactive Strike**](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=48)
[**Shield Block**](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=75) --- **Speed** 25 feet **Melee** _flaming longsword_ +38 ([Fire](/Traits.aspx?ID=72), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103), [versatile P](/Traits.aspx?ID=200)), **Damage** 6d8+18 slashing plus 2d10 fire **Melee** fist +39 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179), [Fire](/Traits.aspx?ID=72), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103)), **Damage** 5d8+18 bludgeoning plus 2d10 fire **Ranged** _flaming javelin_ +34 ([Fire](/Traits.aspx?ID=72), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103), [thrown 30 feet](/Traits.aspx?ID=195)), **Damage** 6d6+18 piercing plus 2d10 fire **Champion Devotion Spells 1 Focus Point,** DC 39 - **10th** [Touch of the Void](/Spells.aspx?ID=2048) **Devastating Blast** ([Arcane](/Traits.aspx?ID=11), [fire 11d12 fire](/Traits.aspx?ID=72)) **Graveknight's Curse** This curse affects anyone who wears Seldeg's armor for at least 1 hour. **Saving Throw** DC 39 Will save; Onset 1 hour; Stage 1 [doomed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=67) 1, and the wearer can't remove the armor (1 day); Stage 2 doomed 2, –10-foot status penalty to Speeds, and the wearer can't remove the armor (1 day); Stage 3 the wearer dies and transforms into Seldeg. **Phantom Mount** ([Arcane](/Traits.aspx?ID=11)) Seldeg summons a supernatural mount as per [_marvelous mount_](/Spells.aspx?ID=1594) (10th rank). Unlike marvelous mount, the mount's AC and saving throw bonuses are all 4 levels lower than Seldeg's, and the mount has one-third of Seldeg's Hit Points (rounded down). If the mount is destroyed, Seldeg must wait 1 hour before using this ability again.
**HP** 155; **AC** 42; **Fort** +32, **Ref** +28, **Will** +29 **Ruinous Weapons** Any weapon or unarmed attack Seldeg uses gains the effects of the [_+1 greater striking_ ](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2829) and [_greater flaming_](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2838) runes. **Swap Fates** ([Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48), [Teleportation](/Traits.aspx?ID=156)) Frequency once per round; Effect Seldeg switches the fates of two creatures within 500 feet. The two creatures teleport into each other's spaces. Each creature then attempts a DC 39 Will save.
**Critical Success** The target becomes temporarily immune to Swap Fates for 24 hours.
**Success** The target takes 3d6 mental damage.
**Failure** The target takes 6d6 mental damage and is [stunned](/Conditions.aspx?ID=93) 1.
**Critical Failure** The target takes 12d6 mental damage and is stunned 4. **Unyielding Block** At the start of each of Seldeg's turns, he gains two additional reactions he can use only to perform a [Shield Block](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=75). **Weapon Master** Seldeg has access to the [critical specialization](/Rules.aspx?ID=2203) effects of any weapon he wields.
name: Seldeg Bhedlis (Claws of the Tyrant)

_Nethys Note: This description was taken from the legacy entry of the monster. _ A [will-o'-wisp](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=210) that starves to death might rise as a cold, blue, glowing sphere of spongy wetness—a corpselight. A corpselight instinctively seeks out a host corpse to dwell within, as its physical form quickly deteriorates if not hidden within a dead creature. **[Recall Knowledge - Undead](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Religion](/Skills.aspx?ID=46)): DC 21 **[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 19 **[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 16 [Corpselight](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3833) **Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 24 **Perception** +7; corpse sense (precise) 30 feet, darkvision **Languages** [Common](/Languages.aspx?ID=1), [Necril](/Languages.aspx?ID=20) **Skills** [Athletics](/Skills.aspx?ID=36) +7, [Intimidation](/Skills.aspx?ID=40) +8, [Stealth](/Skills.aspx?ID=48) +8 **Str** +3 **Dex** +4 **Con** +1 **Int** +1 **Wis** +1 **Cha** +2 **Corpse Sense** A corpselight can sense dead bodies withinrange. This is a precise sense that functions through solid barriers less than 5 feet thick.
 --- **AC** 17 **Fort** +5 **Ref** +10 **Will** +7 **HP** 40 ([void healing](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=83)) **Immunities** [bleed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=86), [death effects](/Traits.aspx?ID=571), [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=578), [fear](/Traits.aspx?ID=598), [paralyzed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=85), [poison](/Traits.aspx?ID=669), precision, [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=95) **Weaknesses** bludgeoning 5 (in skeletal corpses) or slashing 5 (in fleshy corpses) **Sunlight Powerlessness** While in sunlight, a corpselight is [stunned](/Conditions.aspx?ID=93) 2 and [clumsy](/Conditions.aspx?ID=61) 2, and it can't Claim a Corpse.
**Wisp Form** When a corpselight is reduced to 0 Hit Points while merged with a corpse, it is instead reduced to 1 Hit Point as the corpse collapses to the ground and the corpselight emerges in its wisp form. While in wisp form, a corpselight is Tiny and can take no actions other than Claim Corpse or [Fly](/Actions.aspx?ID=2312). A corpselight that starts its turn in wisp form must attempt a DC 16 flat check at the end of its turn; if it fails, it loses 1 Hit Point. A corpselight reduced to 0 Hit Points while in wisp form is destroyed. --- **Speed** 25 feet, fly 25 feet (wisp form only) **Melee** jaws +10, **Damage** 1d8+6 piercing **Melee** claw +10 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170)), **Damage** 1d6+6 slashing **Claim Corpse** **Requirements** The corpselight is in wisp form and is adjacent to a Medium or Small corpse that hasn't been claimed by a corpselight in the past 24 hours; **Effect** The corpselight merges with the corpse, causes the corpse to [Stand](/Actions.aspx?ID=2303), and regains 3d6 Hit Points. **Death Light** ([Emotion](/Traits.aspx?ID=60), [Fear](/Traits.aspx?ID=68), [Mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=106), [Occult](/Traits.aspx?ID=120)) **Requirements** The corpselight is in a corpse; **Effect** The corpselight emits a sickly blue beam of light from its mouth and eyes in a 20-foot cone. All living creatures in this area must attempt a DC 18 Fortitude saving throw. If at least one creature fails its save, the corpselight regains 2d6 Hit Points, gaining any that exceed its maximum as temporary Hit Points that last for 1 minute. The corpselight can't use Death Light again for 1d4 rounds.
**Critical Success** The creature is unaffected.
**Success** The creature takes 1d6 void damage.
**Failure** The creature takes 2d6 void damage and is [frightened](/Conditions.aspx?ID=76) 1.
**Critical Failure** The creature takes 4d6 void damage and is frightened 3.
name: Corpselight

_Nethys Note: No description has been given for this monster._ **[Recall Knowledge - Construct](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Arcana](/Skills.aspx?ID=35), [Crafting](/Skills.aspx?ID=37)): DC 37 **[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 35 **[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 32 [Divine Warden Of Iomedae](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3842) **Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 71 **Perception** +27; darkvision **Languages** **Skills** [Intimidation](/Skills.aspx?ID=40) +32 **Str** +0 **Dex** +9 **Con** +6 **Int** -5 **Wis** +4 **Cha** -5 **Items** [Longsword](/Weapons.aspx?ID=31) --- **AC** 37 **Fort** +30 **Ref** +28 **Will** +33 **HP** 290 **Immunities** [bleed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=86), [death effects](/Traits.aspx?ID=571), [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=578), [doomed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=67), [drained](/Conditions.aspx?ID=68), [fatigued](/Conditions.aspx?ID=73), [healing](/Traits.aspx?ID=623), [mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=647), [nonlethal attacks](/Traits.aspx?ID=661), [paralyzed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=85), [poison](/Traits.aspx?ID=669), [sickened](/Conditions.aspx?ID=91), [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=95), [vitality](/Traits.aspx?ID=509), [void](/Traits.aspx?ID=510) **Resistances** physical 10 **Divine Destruction** ([divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=579), [spirit](/Traits.aspx?ID=737)) When the divine warden is reduced to 0 HP, it erupts with divine energy in a 30-foot [emanation](/Rules.aspx?ID=2387), dealing 16d6 spirit damage. Each creature in the area must attempt a DC 37 Will save.
**Critical Success** The creature takes half damage.
**Success** The creature takes full damage.
**Failure** The creature takes full damage and becomes temporarily cursed by the patron deity. The cursed creature is [enfeebled](/Conditions.aspx?ID=71) 1 and [stupefied](/Conditions.aspx?ID=94) 1 for 1 day; this is a [curse](/Traits.aspx?ID=566) effect that uses the Will save DC as the [counteract](/Rules.aspx?ID=3280) DC.
**Critical Failure** As failure, except the cursed creature is enfeebled 2 and stupefied 2.
**God-Bound** The divine warden is bound to a specific patron deity upon its creation. The warden can't take hostile actions against a creature that openly wears or displays a symbol of its patron deity unless that creature uses a hostile action against the warden first. The warden gains an initial domain spell chosen from its deity's list of domains. The divine warden has 3 Focus Points. --- **Speed** 25 feet **Melee** greater striking longsword +33 ([Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103), [versatile P](/Traits.aspx?ID=200)), **Damage** 3d8+19 slashing **Divine Innate Spells** DC 37, attack +29 - **Cantrips (8th)** [Divine Lance](/Spells.aspx?ID=84) **Cleric Domain Spells 3 Focus Points,** DC 37 - **5th** [Weapon Surge](/Spells.aspx?ID=469) **Faithful Weapon** While the divine warden wields the favored weapon of its patron deity, that weapon gains the effect of a [_greater striking_](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2829) rune. **Instrument of Faith** The divine warden is a beacon for its deity's faith. A cleric of the divine warden's patron deity can channel a [_heal_](/Spells.aspx?ID=1554) spell through a divine warden they can see within 60 feet. The cleric determines any targets or area for the spell as if they were standing in the divine warden's space.
name: Divine Warden Of Iomedae

_Nethys Note: No description has been provided for this creature._ **[Recall Knowledge - Construct](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Arcana](/Skills.aspx?ID=35), [Crafting](/Skills.aspx?ID=37)): DC 37 **[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 35 **[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 32 [Divine Warden Of Arazni](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3844) **Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 73 **Perception** +27; darkvision **Languages** **Skills** [Intimidation](/Skills.aspx?ID=40) +32 **Str** +0 **Dex** +9 **Con** +6 **Int** -5 **Wis** +4 **Cha** -5 **Items** [Rapier](/Weapons.aspx?ID=36) --- **AC** 37 **Fort** +30 **Ref** +28 **Will** +33 **HP** 290 **Immunities** [bleed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=86), [death effects](/Traits.aspx?ID=571), [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=578), [doomed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=67), [drained](/Conditions.aspx?ID=68), [fatigued](/Conditions.aspx?ID=73), [healing](/Traits.aspx?ID=623), [mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=647), [nonlethal attacks](/Traits.aspx?ID=661), [paralyzed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=85), [poison](/Traits.aspx?ID=669), [sickened](/Conditions.aspx?ID=91), [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=95), [vitality](/Traits.aspx?ID=509), [void](/Traits.aspx?ID=510) **Resistances** physical 10 **Divine Destruction** ([divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=579), [spirit](/Traits.aspx?ID=737)) When the divine warden is reduced to 0 HP, it erupts with divine energy in a 30-foot emanation, dealing 16d6 spirit damage. Each creature in the area must attempt a DC 37 Will save.
**Critical Success** The creature takes half damage.
**Success** The creature takes full damage.
**Failure** The creature takes full damage and becomes temporarily cursed by the patron deity. The cursed creature is [enfeebled](/Conditions.aspx?ID=71) 1 and [stupefied](/Conditions.aspx?ID=94) 1 for 1 day; this is a [curse](/Traits.aspx?ID=566) effect that uses the Will save DC as the counteract DC.
**Critical Failure** As failure, except the cursed creature is enfeebled 2 and stupefied 2.
**God-Bound** The divine warden is bound to a specific patron deity upon its creation. The warden can't take hostile actions against a creature that openly wears or displays a symbol of its patron deity unless that creature uses a hostile action against the warden first. The warden gains an initial domain spell chosen from its deity's list of domains. The divine warden has 3 Focus Points. --- **Speed** 25 feet **Melee** _greater striking rapier_ +33 ([deadly 2d8](/Traits.aspx?ID=174), [Disarm](/Traits.aspx?ID=175), [Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103)), **Damage** 3d6+19 piercing **Divine Innate Spells** DC 37, attack +29 - **Cantrips (8th)** [Divine Lance](/Spells.aspx?ID=84) **Cleric Domain Spells 3 Focus Points,** DC 37 - **5th** [Savor the Sting](/Spells.aspx?ID=449) **Faithful Weapon** While the divine warden wields the favored weapon of its patron deity, that weapon gains the effect of a [_greater striking_](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2829) rune. **Instrument of Faith** The divine warden is a beacon for its deity's faith. A cleric of the divine warden's patron deity can channel a [_heal_](/Spells.aspx?ID=1554) spell through a divine warden they can see within 60 feet. The cleric determines any targets or area for the spell as if they were standing in the divine warden's space.
name: Divine Warden Of Arazni

markdown:
_Nethys Note: This description was taken from the legacy entry._ Honor and broken oaths bind a last guard to a location they failed to defend in life. There they must keep watch until their duties are fulfilled or they are swayed by a compelling call to war, departing to march to battle. **[Recall Knowledge - Spirit](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Occultism](/Skills.aspx?ID=44)): DC 42 **[Recall Knowledge - Undead](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Religion](/Skills.aspx?ID=46)): DC 42 **[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 40 **[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 37 [Last Guard](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3845) **Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 77 **Perception** +33; darkvision, [lifesense](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=67) 60 feet **Languages** [Common](/Languages.aspx?ID=1), [Elven](/Languages.aspx?ID=4), [Necril](/Languages.aspx?ID=20) **Skills** [Acrobatics](/Skills.aspx?ID=34) +38, [Stealth](/Skills.aspx?ID=48) +38, [Warfare Lore](/Skills.aspx?ID=41) +35 **Str** -5 **Dex** +10 **Con** +10 **Int** +7 **Wis** +7 **Cha** +6 **Battlefield Bound** Without a call to war, a last guard can stray only a short distance from the location they failed to defend, typically 120 feet. Some last guards are instead bound to a province, kingdom, or nation, rather than a specific location. --- **AC** 45 **Fort** +34 **Ref** +36 **Will** +31 **HP** 330 (4 segments, rejuvenation, [void healing](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=83)) **Immunities** [bleed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=86), [death effects](/Traits.aspx?ID=571), [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=578), [paralyzed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=85), [poison](/Traits.aspx?ID=669), precision, [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=95) **Resistances** all damage 10 (except [force](/Traits.aspx?ID=610), [_ghost touch_](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2840), [spirit](/Traits.aspx?ID=737), or [vitality](/Traits.aspx?ID=509); double resistance vs. non-magical) **Weaknesses** area damage 20, [splash damage](/Traits.aspx?ID=699) 10 **Rejuvenation** ([divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=579)) When a last guard is destroyed, they re-form after 2d4 days within the location they're bound to, fully healed. A last guard can be permanently destroyed and move on to the afterlife only if they successfully defend the location they're bound to from large-scale attack, or fulfill a call to war.
[Troop Defenses](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=86) --- **Speed** fly 40 feet; troop movement **Frightful Battle Cry** ([Auditory](/Traits.aspx?ID=16), [Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48), [Emotion](/Traits.aspx?ID=60), [Fear](/Traits.aspx?ID=68), [Mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=106), [Sonic](/Traits.aspx?ID=147)) The last guards unleash a soul-shaking bellow in unison. All creatures in a 60-foot cone take 7d6 sonic damage (DC 42 [basic](/Rules.aspx?ID=2297) Will save). Any creature that fails its save is also [frightened](/Conditions.aspx?ID=76) 3 (or frightened 4 on a critical failure). If the troop occupies 2 or fewer segments, this area decreases to a 30-foot cone. **Ghostly Blades** **Frequency** once per round; **Effect** The last guards engage in a coordinated attack with their spectral curved blades against each enemy within 5 feet (DC 40 basic Reflex save). The damage depends on the number of actions.
1d8+2 slashing and 1d8 void damage
2d8+14 slashing and 2d8 void damage
3d8+14 slashing and 3d8 void damage **Spectral Charge** The last guards charge, swarming through their foes. The troop [Flies](/Actions.aspx?ID=2312) up to double its Speed, dealing 4d8 void damage to each creature whose space it moves through (DC 40 basic Reflex save). Any creature that fails its save is also [drained](/Conditions.aspx?ID=68) 1 (or drained 2 on a critical failure). The troop can affect each creature only once in a single use of Spectral Charge. **Troop Movement** Whenever the troop Strides, they first Form Up as a free action to condense into a 20-foot-by-20-foot area (minus any missing segments), then move up to their Speed. This works just like a Gargantuan creature moving.
name: Last Guard
resistance_markdown: all damage 10 (except [force](/Traits.aspx?ID=610), [_ghost touch_](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2840), [spirit](/Traits.aspx?ID=737), or [vitality](/Traits.aspx?ID=509); double resistance vs. non-magical)

**Mist Escape** --- **Speed** 25 feet, climb 25 feet **Melee** claws +33 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170)), **Damage** 4d8+17 slashing plus [Grab](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=45) **Melee** dagger +35 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103), [versatile S](/Traits.aspx?ID=200)), **Damage** 4d4+17 piercing **Ranged** dagger +35 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103), [thrown 10 feet](/Traits.aspx?ID=195), [versatile S](/Traits.aspx?ID=200)), **Damage** 4d4+17 piercing **Change Shape** ([Concentrate](/Traits.aspx?ID=32), [Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48), [Polymorph](/Traits.aspx?ID=127)) [Giant bat](/Monsters.aspx?ID=2849) with fangs +33 for 4d8+17 piercing. **Create Servitor** ([Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48), [Downtime](/Traits.aspx?ID=49)) **Dominate** ([Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48), [Incapacitation](/Traits.aspx?ID=93), [Mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=106), [Visual](/Traits.aspx?ID=163)) DC 38 **Drink Blood** ([Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48)) When Drinking Blood, the Lady Siccale regains 36 HP. **Poison Weapon** Lady Siccale applies poison to a dagger. **Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 95

**Languages**
[Diabolic](/Languages.aspx?ID=117), [Draconic](/Languages.aspx?ID=2), [Empyrean](/Languages.aspx?ID=115), [Necril](/Languages.aspx?ID=20); truespeech

**Skills**
[Athletics](/Skills.aspx?ID=36) +34, [Deception](/Skills.aspx?ID=38) +36, [Diplomacy](/Skills.aspx?ID=39) +38, [Intimidation](/Skills.aspx?ID=40) +36, [Medicine](/Skills.aspx?ID=42) +36, [Nature](/Skills.aspx?ID=43) +34, [Survival](/Skills.aspx?ID=49) +38

<row gap="medium">
**Str** +8

**Dex** +6

**Con** +8

**Int** +6

**Wis** +10

**Cha** +8
</row>

**Items**
_[+3 greater striking](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2829) [sickle](/Weapons.aspx?ID=364)_

</column>

---

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="medium">
**AC** 45 

**Fort** +36 

**Ref** +34 

**Will** +38 

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**HP** 475
([void healing](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=83))

</row>

**Immunities**
[death effects](/Traits.aspx?ID=571), [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=578), [paralyzed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=85), [poison](/Traits.aspx?ID=669), [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=95)

**Resistances**
[cold](/Traits.aspx?ID=555) 20

**Weaknesses**
[cold iron](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2916) 20, [fire](/Traits.aspx?ID=604) 20

</column>

---

<column gap="tiny">

**Speed** 40 feet, fly 40 feet

**Melee**
<actions string="Single Action" />
sickle +39 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103), [Trip](/Traits.aspx?ID=196)),
**Damage** 3d4+16 slashing plus 4d6 cold and 1d6 spirit

**Melee**
<actions string="Single Action" />
vine +39 ([reach 20 feet](/Traits.aspx?ID=192)),
**Damage** 4d12+16 bludgeoning plus 1d6 spirit and [Improved Grab](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=66)

**Divine Innate Spells** DC 42, attack +32
- **6th**
[Cursed Metamorphosis](/Spells.aspx?ID=1479) (at will), [Tangling Creepers](/Spells.aspx?ID=331) (at will)
- **8th**
[Arctic Rift](/Spells.aspx?ID=1444) (at will), [Sunburst](/Spells.aspx?ID=326) (at will)
- **9th**
[Nature's Pathway](/Spells.aspx?ID=1613) (at will), [Regenerate](/Spells.aspx?ID=248) (×3), [Wrathful Storm](/Spells.aspx?ID=1759)
- **10th**
[Cataclysm](/Spells.aspx?ID=32), [Remake](/Spells.aspx?ID=249), [Revival](/Spells.aspx?ID=262)
- **Constant (9th)**
[Environmental Endurance](/Spells.aspx?ID=1517), [Speak with Animals](/Spells.aspx?ID=293), [Speak with Plants](/Spells.aspx?ID=294), [Truespeech](/Spells.aspx?ID=1728)

**Rituals** DC 42

- **2nd**
[Consecrate](/Rituals.aspx?ID=8)
- **4th**
[Blight](/Rituals.aspx?ID=4), [Plant Growth](/Rituals.aspx?ID=18)
- **6th**
[Awaken Animal](/Rituals.aspx?ID=3), [Primal Call](/Rituals.aspx?ID=19)

**Alter Weather** <actions string="Three Actions" />   **Frequency** three times per day **Effect** The veranallia dramatically alters weather patterns in the surrounding area, producing any of the results of a successful 9th-rank [_control weather_](/Rituals.aspx?ID=116) ritual.

**Rebirth**  ([Divine](/Traits.aspx?ID=48)) **Frequency** once per day; **Effect** The veranallia spends a minute to encase a creature that has been dead for no more than a year in a cocoon. After 24 hours, the creature is restored to life, and the cocoon explodes in a shower of dust. If the veranallia chooses, Rebirth can change the creature's ancestry or heritage, typically into a [skeleton](/MonsterFamilies.aspx?ID=472).

</column>

_Nethys Note: No description has been given for this creature._ **[Recall Knowledge - Undead](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)** ([Religion](/Skills.aspx?ID=46)): DC 50 **[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 48 **[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 45 [Chained Norn](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3849) **Source** [Claws of the Tyrant](/Sources.aspx?ID=266) pg. 96 **Perception** +41; [_detect magic_](/Spells.aspx?ID=1485), [greater darkvision](/Rules.aspx?ID=2410), [lifesense](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=67) 120 feet, [_truesight_](/Spells.aspx?ID=1727) **Languages** [Common](/Languages.aspx?ID=1), [Fey](/Languages.aspx?ID=119), [Jotun](/Languages.aspx?ID=8); [_truespeech_](/Spells.aspx?ID=1728) **Skills** [Crafting](/Skills.aspx?ID=37) +36, [Deception](/Skills.aspx?ID=38) +35, [Intimidation](/Skills.aspx?ID=40) +37, [Lore](/Skills.aspx?ID=41) +28, [Medicine](/Skills.aspx?ID=42) +38, [Occultism](/Skills.aspx?ID=44) +34, [Performance](/Skills.aspx?ID=45) +31, [Religion](/Skills.aspx?ID=46) +34 **Str** +7 **Dex** +6 **Con** +6 **Int** +6 **Wis** +10 **Cha** +7 **Broken Fate** ([misfortune](/Traits.aspx?ID=654)) The chained norn automatically rolls a 1 when she rolls initiative.
**Broken Triumvirate** The chained norn's fate has been severed from the rest of the norns. She can't join a triumvirate or willingly take a hostile action against a norn. --- **AC** 46 **Fort** +34 **Ref** +30 **Will** +38 +1 status to all saves vs. magic **HP** 375 ([void healing](/MonsterAbilities.aspx?ID=83)) , regeneration 20 (deactivated by [cold iron](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2916)) **Immunities** [bleed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=86), [death effects](/Traits.aspx?ID=571), [disease](/Traits.aspx?ID=578), [off-guard](/Conditions.aspx?ID=58), [paralyzed](/Conditions.aspx?ID=85), [poison](/Traits.aspx?ID=669), [unconscious](/Conditions.aspx?ID=95) **Weaknesses** [cold iron](/Equipment.aspx?ID=2916) 20 **Broken Fates Aura** ([aura](/Traits.aspx?ID=542), [mental](/Traits.aspx?ID=647), [misfortune](/Traits.aspx?ID=654), [occult](/Traits.aspx?ID=662)) 60 feet. Creatures other than norns in the aura must attempt a DC 42 Will save. On a successful save, the creature is temporarily immune to the broken fates aura for 24 hours. On a failure, the creature can't benefit from effects with the [fortune](/Traits.aspx?ID=612) trait for 24 hours.
**Rewind Fate** ([misfortune](/Traits.aspx?ID=654), [occult ](/Traits.aspx?ID=662)) **Trigger** A creature within 120 feet would succeed on an attack or skill check; **Effect** The creature must attempt the attack or skill check again, rolling twice and taking the worse result. --- **Speed** 35 feet, fly 35 feet **Melee** hand of fate +38 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [Magical](/Traits.aspx?ID=103), [reach 10 feet](/Traits.aspx?ID=192)), **Damage** 4d10+15 void plus sever fate **Occult Innate Spells** DC 42 - **7th** [Dispel Magic](/Spells.aspx?ID=78) (at will), [Read Omens](/Spells.aspx?ID=247) (at will), [Spellwrack](/Spells.aspx?ID=298) (at will) - **8th** [Migration](/Spells.aspx?ID=1600), [Quandary](/Spells.aspx?ID=1644) - **9th** [Execute](/Spells.aspx?ID=1519), [Phantasmagoria](/Spells.aspx?ID=1629), [Retrocognition](/Spells.aspx?ID=260) - **10th** [Freeze Time](/Spells.aspx?ID=1538) - **Constant (10th)** [Detect Magic](/Spells.aspx?ID=66), [Hidden Mind](/Spells.aspx?ID=1556), [Truesight](/Spells.aspx?ID=1727), [Truespeech](/Spells.aspx?ID=1728) **Rituals** DC 42 - **3rd** [Geas](/Rituals.aspx?ID=12) - **7th** [Collective Memories](/Rituals.aspx?ID=113) **Fated** When a creature is subject to a [misfortune](/Traits.aspx?ID=654) effect from a norn and a [fortune](/Traits.aspx?ID=612) effect from any source other than a norn (or vice versa), the norn’s effect automatically [counteracts](/Rules.aspx?ID=2250) the other effect and then takes place normally, rather than the two effects canceling each other out. If both the fortune and misfortune effect are from a norn, then the two cancel each other out as normal. At the GM’s discretion, powerful entities related to fate or luck, like [Desna](/Deities.aspx?ID=281), [Magdh](/Deities.aspx?ID=457), or [Pharasma](/Deities.aspx?ID=290), can’t have their effects negated by this ability. **Sever Fate** ([Occult](/Traits.aspx?ID=120)) When a norn deals void damage with a Strike, she regains 10 Hit Points. The target must succeed at a DC 39 Fortitude save or become [drained](/Conditions.aspx?ID=68) 1 (drained 2 on a critical failure). Further void damage dealt by the norn increases the drained condition value by 1 on a failed save (or by 2 on a critical failure), to a maximum of drained 4.
name: Chained Norn

<title level="1" pfs="">[Batkin Guard](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3850)</title>

<row gap="medium">

<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">

Unlike true werecreatures, [beastkin](/Traits.aspx?ID=337) aren't affected by silver or the full moon, though they can still adopt a hybrid form. 

<column gap="tiny">
**[Recall Knowledge - Beast](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**
([Arcana](/Skills.aspx?ID=35), [Nature](/Skills.aspx?ID=43)): DC 17

**[Recall Knowledge - Humanoid](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**
([Society](/Skills.aspx?ID=47)): DC 17

**[Unspecific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 15

**[Specific Lore](/Rules.aspx?ID=563)**: DC 12
</column>

</column>

<column gap="medium">

</column>

</row>

<title level="2" right="Creature 1">[Batkin Guard](/Monsters.aspx?ID=3850)</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Uncommon" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=721" />
<trait label="Medium" />
<trait label="Beast" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=547" />
<trait label="Beastkin" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=337" />
<trait label="Human" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=627" />
<trait label="Humanoid" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=628" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

**Source** [Pathfinder #213: Thirst for Blood](/Sources.aspx?ID=257) pg. 88

**Perception** +6

**Languages**
[Common](/Languages.aspx?ID=1)

**Skills**
[Acrobatics](/Skills.aspx?ID=34) +7, [Athletics](/Skills.aspx?ID=36) +5, [Deception](/Skills.aspx?ID=38) +4, [Stealth](/Skills.aspx?ID=48) +5

<row gap="medium">
**Str** +4

**Dex** +2

**Con** +2

**Int** +0

**Wis** +0

**Cha** +1
</row>

**Quick Change** <actions string="Free Action" /> **Trigger** The batkin rolls initiative; **Effect** The batkin's instincts kick in, and they take on an aggressive stance. The batkin uses Change Shape to enter their hybrid form.

**Items**
[minor elixir of life](/Equipment.aspx?ID=91), [Morningstar](/Weapons.aspx?ID=8), [Scale Mail](/Armor.aspx?ID=8), [Shortbow](/Weapons.aspx?ID=77) (20 arrows)

</column>

---

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="medium">
**AC** 15 

**Fort** +7 

**Ref** +7 

**Will** +3 

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**HP** 20

</row>

</column>

---

<column gap="tiny">

**Speed** 25 feet

**Melee**
<actions string="Single Action" />
morningstar +7 ([versatile P](/Traits.aspx?ID=200)),
**Damage** 1d6+4 bludgeoning

**Melee**
<actions string="Single Action" />
jaws +7 ([Agile](/Traits.aspx?ID=170), [Finesse](/Traits.aspx?ID=179), [Unarmed](/Traits.aspx?ID=199)),
**Damage** 1d4+4 piercing

**Ranged**
<actions string="Single Action" />
shortbow +5 ([deadly d10](/Traits.aspx?ID=174), [range increment 60 feet](/Traits.aspx?ID=248)),
**Damage** 1d6 piercing

**Change Shape** <actions string="Single Action" /> ([[concentrate](/Traits.aspx?ID=561)](/Traits.aspx?ID=32), [[polymorph](/Traits.aspx?ID=670)](/Traits.aspx?ID=113), [[primal](/Traits.aspx?ID=676)](/Traits.aspx?ID=134)) The batkin changes into their humanoid or hybrid shape. Each shape has a specific, persistent appearance. In hybrid shape, the batkin appears as a mix between human and a bat. While in hybrid shape, they gain a jaws unarmed Strike resembling a bat's fangs. In their humanoid shape, they retain the appearance of their original ancestry.

**Snagging Strike** <actions string="Single Action" />  **Requirements** The batkin has one hand free, and their target is within reach of that hand; Effect The batkin makes a Strike while keeping one hand free. If this Strike hits, the target is [off-guard](/Conditions.aspx?ID=58) until the start of the batkin's next turn or until the target is no longer within the reach of the batkin's hand, whichever comes first.

</column>

<aside>
<title level="2" noclass="true" icon="/images/Icons/Sidebar_2_AdditionalLore.png">Camazotz's Gifts</title>

[Camazotz](/Deities.aspx?ID=334) generally pays no mind to his mortal worshippers. However, when a follower does win Camazotz's favor, the bat god might grant that follower a gift. The most common of these boons is a bat [familiar](/Feats.aspx?ID=5024) or [animal companion](/Feats.aspx?ID=4708), but in some cases Camazotz transforms the faithful servant into a batkin. Only the most exceptional of Camazotz's followers are transformed into werebats.
</aside>

<document level="2" id="creature-family-484" />
name: Batkin Guard
